body: Modulating or throttling is the action of a control from its maximum to minimum position in either pre-determined steps or increments of movement as caused by its actuating medium.

title: Multiple-Station Smoke Alarm
body: Two or more single-station alarm devices that are capable of interconnection such that actuation of one causes all integral or separate audible alarms to operate.

title: Nailable Substrate
body: A product or material such as framing, sheathing or furring, composed of wood or wood-based materials, or other materials and fasteners providing equivalent fastener withdrawal resistance.

title: Natural Draft System
body: A venting system designed to remove flue or vent gases under nonpositive static vent pressure entirely by natural draft.

title: Naturally Durable Wood
body: The heartwood of the following species with the exception that an occasional piece with corner sapwood is permitted if 90 percent or more of the width of each side on which it occurs is heartwood.

title: Decay Resistant
body: Redwood, cedar, black locust and black walnut.

title: Termite Resistant
body: Alaska yellow cedar, redwood, Eastern red cedar and Western red cedar including all sapwood of Western red cedar.

title: Noncombustible Material
body: Materials that pass the test procedure for defining noncombustibility of elementary materials set forth in ASTM E136.

title: Noncombustible Materials (Chapter 24 Fuel Gas)
body: Materials that, where tested in accordance with ASTM E136, have not fewer than three of four specimens tested meeting all of the following criteria: The recorded temperature of the surface and interior thermocouples shall not at any time during the test rise more than 54°F (30°C) above the furnace temperature at the beginning of the test. There shall not be flaming from the specimen after the first 30 seconds. If the weight loss of the specimen during testing exceeds 50 percent, the recorded temperature of the surface and interior thermocouples shall not at any time during the test rise above the furnace air temperature at the beginning of the test, and there shall not be flaming of the specimen.

title: Nosing
body: The leading edge of treads of stairs and of landings at the top of stairway flights.

title: Occupied Space
body: The total area of all buildings or structures on any lot or parcel of ground projected on a horizontal plane, excluding permitted projections as allowed by this code.

title: Offset
body: A combination of fittings that makes two changes in direction, bringing one section of the pipe out of line and into a line parallel with the other section.

title: Offset (Vent)
body: A combination of approved bends that make two changes in direction bringing one section of the vent out of line, but into a line parallel with the other section.

title: On-Site Nonpotable Water Reuse Systems
body: Water systems for the collection, treatment, storage, distribution, and reuse of nonpotable water generated on site, including but not limited to graywater systems. This definition does not include rainwater harvesting systems.

title: Opaque Door
body: A door that is not less than 50-percent opaque in surface area.

title: Outlet (Chapter 24 Fuel Gas)
body: The point at which a gasfired appliance connects to the gas piping system.

title: Owner
body: Any person, agent, firm or corporation having a legal or equitable interest in the property.

title: Oxygen Depletion Safety Shutoff System (ODS)
body: A system designed to act to shut off the gas supply to the main and pilot burners if the oxygen in the surrounding atmosphere is reduced below a predetermined level.

title: Pan Flashing
body: Corrosion-resistant flashing at the base of an opening that is integrated into the building exterior wall to direct water to the exterior and is premanufactured, fabricated, formed or applied at the job site.

title: Panel Thickness
body: Thickness of core plus two layers of structural wood panel facings.

title: Pellet Fuel-Burning Appliance
body: A closed combustion, vented appliance equipped with a fuel feed mechanism for burning processed pellets of solid fuel of a specified size and composition.

title: Pellet Vent
body: A vent listed and labeled for use with a listed pellet fuel-burning appliance.

title: Performance Category
body: A designation of wood structural panels as related to the panel performance used in Chapters 4, 5, 6 and 8.

title: Permit
body: An approval indicated in an official document or certificate issued by the residential building official that authorizes performance of a specified activity. Also see "APPROVED".

title: Person
body: An individual, heirs, executors, administrators or assigns, and a firm, partnership or corporation, its or their successors or assigns, or the agent of any of the aforesaid.

title: Photovoltaic Module
body: A complete, environmentally protected unit consisting of solar cells, optics and other components, exclusive of a tracker, designed to generate DC power where exposed to sunlight.

title: Photovoltaic Panel
body: A collection of photovoltaic modules mechanically fastened together, wired, and designed to provide a field-installable unit.

title: Photovoltaic Panel System
body: A system that incorporates discrete photovoltaic panels that convert solar radiation into electricity, including rack support systems.

title: Photovoltaic Shingles
body: A roof covering that resembles shingles and that incorporates photovoltaic modules.

title: Pilot
body: A small flame that is utilized to ignite the gas at the main burner or burners.

title: Piping (Chapter 24 Fuel Gas)
body: Where used in this code, "piping" refers to either pipe or tubing, or both.

title: Pipe
body: A rigid conduit of iron, steel, copper, copper-alloy or plastic.

title: Tubing
body: Semi-rigid conduit of copper, copper-alloy, aluminum, plastic or steel.

title: Piping System (Chapter 24 Fuel Gas)
body: The fuel piping, valves and fittings from the outlet of the point of delivery to the outlets of the appliance shutoff valves.

title: Pitch
body: See "Slope."

title: Plastic Composite
body: A generic designation that refers to wood-plastic composites and plastic lumber.

title: Plastic, Thermoplastic
body: A plastic that is capable of being repeatedly softened by increase of temperature and hardened by decrease of temperature.

title: Platform Construction
body: A method of construction by which floor framing bears on load bearing walls that are not continuous through the story levels or floor framing.

title: Plenum
body: A chamber that forms part of an air-circulation system other than the occupied space being conditioned.

title: Plumbing
body: The practice, materials and fixtures utilized in the installation, maintenance, extension and alteration of all piping, fixtures, appliances and appurtenances within or adjacent to any structure, in connection with sanitary drainage or storm drainage facilities; venting systems; and public or private water supply systems.

title: Plumbing Appliance
body: An energized household appliance with plumbing connections, such as a dishwasher, food waste disposer, clothes washer or water heater.

title: Plumbing Appurtenance
body: A device or assembly that is an adjunct to the basic plumbing system and does not demand additional water supply or add any discharge load to the system. It is presumed that it performs some useful function in the operation, maintenance, servicing, economy or safety of the plumbing system. Examples include filters, relief valves and aerators.

title: Plumbing Fixture
body: A receptacle or device that is connected to a water supply system or discharges to a drainage system or both. Such receptacles or devices require a supply of water; or discharge liquid waste or liquidborne solid waste; or require a supply of water and discharge waste to a drainage system.

title: Plumbing Systems
body: Includes the water distribution pipes; plumbing fixtures and traps; water-treating or water-using equipment; soil, waste and vent pipes; and building drains; in addition to their respective connections, devices and appurtenances within a structure or premises; and the water service, building sewer and building storm sewer serving such structure or premises.

title: Point of Delivery (Chapter 24 Fuel Gas)
body: For natural gas systems, the point of delivery is the outlet of the service meter assembly or the outlet of the service regulator or service shutoff valve where a meter is not provided. Where a valve is provided at the outlet of the service meter assembly, such valve shall be considered to be downstream of the point of delivery. For undiluted liquefied petroleum gas systems, the point of delivery shall be considered to be the outlet of the service pressure regulator, exclusive of line gas regulators, in the system.

title: Pollution
body: A low-hazard or nonhealth-hazard impairment of the quality of the potable water to a degree that does not create a hazard to the public health and that does adversely and unreasonably affect the aesthetic qualities of such potable water for domestic use.

title: Polypropylene Siding
body: A shaped material, made principally from polypropylene homopolymer, or copolymer, that in some cases contains fillers or reinforcements, that is used to clad exterior walls or buildings.

title: Portable-Fuel-Cell Appliance
body: A fuel cell generator of electricity that is not fixed in place. A portable-fuel-cell appliance utilizes a cord and plug connection to a grid-isolated load and has an integral fuel supply.

title: Positive Roof Drainage
body: The drainage condition in which consideration has been made for the loading deflections of the roof deck, and additional slope has been provided to ensure drainage of the roof within 48 hours of precipitation.

title: Potable Water
body: Water free from impurities present in amounts sufficient to cause disease or harmful physiological effects and conforming in bacteriological and chemical quality to the requirements of the public health authority having jurisdiction.

title: Precast Concrete
body: A structural concrete element cast elsewhere than its final position in the structure.

title: Precast Concrete Foundation Walls
body: Preengineered, precast concrete wall panels that are designed to withstand specified stresses and used to build below-grade foundations.

title: Pressure Drop (Chapter 24 Fuel Gas)
body: The loss in pressure due to friction or obstruction in pipes, valves, fittings, regulators and burners.

title: Pressure-Relief Valve
body: A pressure-actuated valve held closed by a spring or other means and designed to automatically relieve pressure at the pressure at which it is set.

title: Pressure Test (Chapter 24 Fuel Gas)
body: An operation performed to verify the gas-tight integrity of gas piping following its installation or modification.

title: Process Equipment
body: Equipment, machinery and devices specifically intended and used exclusively for purposes other than building service equipment.

title: Proposed Design
body: A description of the proposed building used to estimate annual energy use for determining compliance based on total building performance.

title: Public Sewer
body: A common sewer directly controlled by public authority.

title: Public Water Main
body: A water-supply pipe for public use controlled by public authority.

title: Public Way
body: Any street, alley or other parcel of land open to the outside air leading to a public street, that has been deeded, dedicated or otherwise permanently appropriated to the public for public use and that has a clear width and height of not less than 10 feet (3048 mm).

title: Purge
body: To clear of air, gas or other foreign substances.

title: Quick-Closing Valve
body: A valve or faucet that closes automatically where released manually or controlled by mechanical means for fast-action closing.

title: Ramp
body: A walking surface that has a running slope steeper than 1 unit vertical in 20 units horizontal (5-percent slope).

title: Rated Design
body: A description of the proposed building used to determine the energy rating index.

title: Readily Accessible
body: Capable of being reached quickly for operation, renewal or inspection without requiring those to whom ready access is requisite to climb over or remove obstacles or to resort to portable ladders or access equipment (see "Accessible").

title: Ready Access (To)
body: That which enables a device, appliance or equipment to be directly reached, without requiring the removal or movement of any panel, door or similar obstruction.

title: Receptor
body: A fixture or device that receives the discharge from indirect waste pipes.

title: Reclaimed Water
body: Nonpotable water that has been derived from the treatment of wastewater by a facility or system licensed or permitted to produce water meeting the jurisdiction's water requirements for its intended uses. Also known as "Recycled water."

title: Refrigerant
body: A substance used to produce refrigeration by its expansion or evaporation.

title: Refrigerant Compressor
body: A specific machine, with or without accessories, for compressing a given refrigerant vapor.

title: Refrigerating System
body: A combination of interconnected parts forming a closed circuit in which refrigerant is circulated for the purpose of extracting, then rejecting, heat. A direct refrigerating system is one in which the evaporator or condenser of the refrigerating system is in direct contact with the air or other substances to be cooled or heated. An indirect refrigerating system is one in which a secondary coolant cooled or heated by the refrigerating system is circulated to the air or other substance to be cooled or heated.

title: Registered Design Professional
body: Any architect holding a certificate issued under Sections 4703.10 and 4703.36 of the Revised Code or any engineer holding a certificate issued under Section 4733.14 of the Revised Code.

title: Regulator
body: A device for controlling and maintaining a uniform gas supply pressure, either pounds-to-inches water column (MP regulator) or inches-to-inches water column (appliance regulator).

title: Regulator, Gas Appliance
body: A pressure regulator for controlling pressure to the manifold of the gas appliance.

title: Regulator, Line Gas Pressure
body: A device placed in a gas line between the service pressure regulator and the appliance for controlling, maintaining or reducing the pressure in that portion of the piping system downstream of the device.

title: Regulator, Medium-Pressure (MP Regulator)
body: A line pressure regulator that reduces gas pressure from the range of greater than 0.5 psig (3.4 kPa) and less than or equal to 5 psig (34.5 kPa) to a lower pressure.

title: Regulator, Pressure
body: A device placed in a gas line for reducing, controlling and maintaining the pressure in that portion of the piping system downstream of the device.

title: Regulator, Service Pressure
body: For natural gas systems, a device installed by the serving gas supplier to reduce and limit the service line pressure to delivery pressure. For undiluted liquefied petroleum gas systems, the regulator located upstream from all line gas pressure regulators, where installed, and downstream from any first stage or a high pressure regulator in the system.

title: Relief Opening
body: The opening provided in a draft hood to permit the ready escape to the atmosphere of the flue products from the draft hood in the event of no draft, backdraft or stoppage beyond the draft hood, and to permit air into the draft hood in the event of a strong chimney updraft.

title: Relief Valve (Device)
body: A safety valve designed to forestall the development of a dangerous condition by relieving either pressure, temperature or vacuum in the hot water supply system.

title: Relief Valve, Pressure
body: An automatic valve that opens and closes a relief vent, depending on whether the pressure is above or below a predetermined value.

title: Manual Reset Type
body: A valve that automatically opens a relief vent at a predetermined temperature and that must be manually returned to the closed position.

title: Reseating or Self-Closing Type
body: An automatic valve that opens and closes a relief vent, depending on whether the temperature is above or below a predetermined value.

title: Relief Valve, Vacuum
body: A device to prevent excessive buildup of vacuum in a pressure vessel.

title: Repair
body: The reconstruction, replacement or renewal of any part of an existing building for the purpose of its maintenance or to correct damage.

title: Repair, Minor
body: The reconstruction or renewal of any part of an existing building for the purpose of its maintenance when the work has limited impact on access, safety or health. Minor repairs do not include the cutting away of any wall, partition or portions of walls, the removal or cutting of any structural beam or load bearing support, or the removal or change of any required element of accessibility, means of egress, or rearrangement of parts of a structure affecting the egress requirements. Minor repairs do not include addition to, alteration of, replacement or relocation of any standpipe, water supply, sewer, drainage, drain leader, gas, soil, waste, vent or similar piping, electric wiring or mechanical or other work affecting public health or general safety.

title: Reroofing
body: The process of recovering or replacing an existing roof covering. See "Roof recover."

title: Residential Building
body: A one-family, two-family, or three-family dwelling house, and any accessory structure incidental to that dwelling house. "Residential building" includes a one-family, two-family, or three-family dwelling house that is used as a model to promote the sale of a similar dwelling house. "Residential building" does not include an industrialized unit as defined by division (C)(3) of Section 3781.06 of the Revised Code, a manufactured home as defined by division (C)(4) of Section 3781.06 of the Revised Code, or a mobile home as defined by division (O) of Section 4501.01 of the Revised Code.

title: Residential Building Official
body: An individual who has received and maintains a certification of "Residential Building Official" in accordance with rules of the board of building standards.

title: Return Air
body: Air removed from an approved conditioned space or location and recirculated or exhausted.

title: Ridge
body: With respect to topographic wind effects, an elongated crest of a hill characterized by strong relief in two directions.

title: Riser, Gas
body: A vertical pipe supplying fuel gas.

title: Riser (Plumbing)
body: A water pipe that extends vertically one full story or more to convey water to branches or to a group of fixtures.

title: Riser (Stair)
body: The vertical component of a step or stair.

title: Roof Assembly
body: A system designed to provide weather protection and resistance to design loads. The system consists of a roof covering and roof deck or a single component serving as both the roof covering and the roof deck. A roof assembly includes the roof deck, underlayment and roof covering, and can also include a thermal barrier, ignition barrier, insulation or a vapor retarder.

title: Roof Coating
body: A fluid-applied, adhered coating used for roof maintenance or roof repair, or as a component of a roof covering system or roof assembly.

title: Roof Covering
body: The covering applied to the roof deck for weather resistance, fire classification or appearance.

title: Roof Covering System
body: See "Roof assembly."

title: Roof Deck
body: The flat or sloped surface not including its supporting members or vertical supports.

title: Roof Recover
body: The process of installing an additional roof covering over a prepared existing roof covering without removing the existing roof covering.

title: Roof Repair
body: Reconstruction or renewal of any part of an existing roof for the purposes of its maintenance.

title: Roof Replacement
body: The process of removing the existing roof covering, repairing any damaged substrate and installing a new roof covering.

title: Room Heater
body: A free-standing heating appliance installed in the space being heated and not connected to ducts.

title: Room Heater, Unvented
body: See "Unvented room heater."

title: Room Heater, Vented
body: See "Vented room heater."

title: Rough-In
body: The installation of the parts of the plumbing system that must be completed prior to the installation of fixtures. This includes DWV, water supply and built-in fixture supports.

title: Running Bond
body: The placement of masonry units such that head joints in successive courses are horizontally offset not less than one-quarter the unit length.

title: R-Value (Thermal Resistance)
body: The inverse of the time rate of heat flow through a body from one of its bounding surfaces to the other surface for a unit temperature difference between the two surfaces, under steady state conditions, per unit area (h • ft2 • °F/Btu) [(m2 • K)/W].

title: Safe
body: As applied to a building, means free from danger or hazard to the life, safety, health or welfare of persons occupying or frequenting it, or of the public, and from danger of settlement, movement, disintegration, or collapse, whether such danger arises from the method or materials of its construction or from equipment installed therein, for the purpose of lighting, heating, the transmission or utilization of electric current, or from its location or otherwise.

title: Safety Shutoff Device
body: See "Flame safeguard."

title: Sanitary
body: As applied to a building, means free from danger or hazard to the health of persons occupying or frequenting it or to that of the public, if such danger arises from the method or materials of its construction or from any equipment installed therein for the purpose of lighting, heating, ventilating, or plumbing.

title: Sanitary Sewer
body: A sewer that carries sewage and excludes storm, surface and groundwater.

title: Scupper
body: An opening in a wall or parapet that allows water to drain from a roof.

title: Seismic Design Category (SDC)
body: A classification assigned to a structure based on its occupancy category and the severity of the design earthquake ground motion at the site.

title: Septic Tank
body: A water-tight receptor that receives the discharge of a building sanitary drainage system and is constructed so as to separate solids from the liquid, digest organic matter through a period of detention, and allow the liquids to discharge into the soil outside of the tank through a system of open joint or perforated piping or a seepage pit.

title: Serious Hazard
body: A hazard of considerable consequence to safety or health through the design, location, construction, or equipment of a building, or the condition thereof, which hazard has been established through experience to be of certain or probable consequence, or which can be determined to be, or which is obviously such a hazard.

title: Service Water Heating
body: Supply of hot water for purposes other than comfort heating.

title: Sewage
body: Any liquid waste containing animal matter, vegetable matter or other impurity in suspension or solution.

title: Sewage Pump
body: A permanently installed mechanical device for removing sewage or liquid waste from a sump.

title: Shaft
body: An enclosed space extending through one or more stories of a building, connecting vertical openings in successive floors, or floors and the roof.

title: Shall
body: The term, where used in the code, is construed as mandatory.

title: Shear Wall
body: A general term for walls that are designed and constructed to resist racking from seismic and wind by use of masonry, concrete, cold-formed steel or wood framing in accordance with Chapter 6 of this code and the applicable limitations in Section 301.2 of this code.

title: Shingle Fashion
body: A method of installing roof or wall coverings, water-resistive barriers, flashing or other building components such that upper layers of material are placed overlapping lower layers of material to provide drainage and protect against water intrusion at unsealed penetrations and joints or in combination with sealed joints.

title: Single-Ply Membrane
body: A roofing membrane that is field applied using one layer of membrane material (either homogeneous or composite) rather than multiple layers.

title: Single-Station Smoke Alarm
body: An assembly incorporating the detector, control equipment and alarm sounding device in one unit that is operated from a power supply either in the unit or obtained at the point of installation.

title: Site-Built Fenestration Product
body: See FENESTRATION, Site-Built Fenestration Product.

title: Skylight
body: See FENESTRATION, Skylights.

title: Skylight, Unit
body: See FENESTRATION, Unit Skylight.

title: Skylights and Sloped Glazing
body: See FENESTRATION, Skylights and Sloped Glazing.

title: Slip Joint
body: A mechanical-type joint used primarily on fixture traps. The joint tightness is obtained by compressing a friction-type washer such as rubber, nylon, neoprene, lead or special packing material against the pipe by the tightening of a (slip) nut.

title: Slope
body: The fall (pitch) of a line of pipe in reference to a horizontal plane. In drainage, the slope is expressed as the fall in units vertical per units horizontal (percent) for a length of pipe.

title: Smoke-Developed Index
body: A comparative measure, expressed as a dimensionless number, derived from measurements of smoke obscuration versus time for a material tested in accordance with ASTM E84 or UL 723.

title: Specific Gravity (Chapter 24 Fuel Gas)
body: As applied to gas, specific gravity is the ratio of the weight of a given volume to that of the same volume of air, both measured under the same condition.

title: Soil Stack or Pipe
body: A pipe that conveys sewage containing fecal material.

title: Solar Energy System
body: A system that converts solar radiation to usable energy, including photovoltaic panel systems and solar thermal systems.

title: Solar Heat Gain Coefficient (SHGC)
body: The ratio of the solar heat gain entering the space through the fenestration assembly to the incident solar radiation. Solar heat gain includes directly transmitted solar heat and absorbed solar radiation that is then reradiated, conducted or convected into the space.

title: Solar Thermal Collector
body: Components in a solar thermal system that collect and convert solar radiation to thermal energy.

title: Solar Thermal System
body: A system that converts solar radiation to thermal energy for use in heating or cooling.

title: Solid Masonry
body: Load-bearing or nonload-bearing construction using masonry units where the net cross-sectional area of each unit in any plane parallel to the bearing surface is not less than 75 percent of its gross cross-sectional area. Solid masonry units shall conform to ASTM C55, C62, C73, C145 or C216.

title: Spline
body: A strip of wood structural panel cut from the same material used for the panel facings, used to connect two structural insulated panels. The strip (spline) fits into a groove cut into the vertical edges of the two structural insulated panels to be joined. Splines are used behind each facing of the structural insulated panels being connected as shown in Figure 610.8.

title: Stack
body: Any main vertical DWV line, including offsets, that extends one or more stories as directly as possible to its vent terminal.

title: Stack Bond
body: The placement of masonry units in a bond pattern is such that head joints in successive courses are vertically aligned. For the purpose of this code, requirements for stack bond shall apply to all masonry laid in other than running bond.

title: Stack Vent
body: The extension of soil or waste stack above the highest horizontal drain connected.

title: Stair
body: A change in elevation, consisting of one or more risers.

title: Stairway
body: One or more flights of stairs, either interior or exterior, with the necessary landings and connecting platforms to form a continuous and uninterrupted passage from one level to another within or attached to a building, porch or deck.

title: Stairway, Spiral
body: A stairway with a plan view of closed circular form and uniform section-shaped treads radiating from a minimum-diameter circle.

title: Standard Reference Design
body: A version of the proposed design that meets the minimum requirements of this code and is used to determine the maximum annual energy use requirement for compliance based on total building performance.

title: Standard Truss
body: Any construction that does not permit the roof-ceiling insulation to achieve the required R-value over the exterior walls.

title: Stationary Fuel Cell Power Plant
body: A self-contained package or factory-matched packages that constitute an automatically-operated assembly of integrated systems for generating useful electrical energy and recoverable thermal energy that is permanently connected and fixed in place.

title: Storm Sewer, Drain
body: A pipe used for conveying rainwater, surface water, subsurface water and similar liquid waste.

title: Story
body: That portion of a building included between the upper surface of a floor and the upper surface of the floor or roof next above.

title: Story Above Grade Plane
body: Any story having its finished floor surface entirely above grade plane, or in which the finished surface of the floor next above is either of the following: More than 6 feet (1829 mm) above grade plane. More than 12 feet (3658 mm) above the finished ground level at any point.

title: Structural Composite Lumber
body: Structural members manufactured using wood elements bonded together with exterior adhesives. Examples of structural composite lumber are:

title: Laminated Strand Lumber (LSL)
body: A composite of wood strand elements with wood fibers primarily oriented along the length of the member, where the least dimension of the wood strand elements is 0.10 inch (2.54 mm) or less and their average lengths are not less than 150 times the least dimension of the wood strand elements.

title: Laminated Veneer Lumber (LVL)
body: A composite of wood veneer elements with wood fibers primarily oriented along the length of the member, where the veneer element thicknesses are 0.25 inch (6.4 mm) or less.

title: Oriented Strand Lumber (OSL)
body: A composite of wood strand elements with wood fibers primarily oriented along the length of the member, where the least dimension of the wood strand elements is 0.10 inch (2.54 mm) or less and their average lengths are not less than 75 times and less than 150 times the least dimension of the wood strand elements.

title: Parallel Strand Lumber (PSL)
body: A composite of wood strand elements with wood fibers primarily oriented along the length of the member, where the least dimension of the wood strand elements is 0.25 inch (6.4 mm) or less and their average lengths are not less than 300 times the least dimension of the wood strand elements.

title: Structural Insulated Panel (SIP)
body: A structural sandwich panel that consists of a lightweight foam plastic core securely laminated between two thin, rigid wood structural panel facings.

title: Structure
body: That which is built or constructed.

title: Subsoil Drain
body: A drain that collects subsurface water or seepage water and conveys such water to a place of disposal.

title: Sump
body: A tank or pit that receives sewage or waste, located below the normal grade of the gravity system and that must be emptied by mechanical means.

title: Sump Pump
body: A pump installed to empty a sump. These pumps are used for removing storm water only. The pump is selected for the specific head and volume of the load and is usually operated by level controllers.

title: Sunroom
body: A one-story structure attached to a dwelling with a glazing area in excess of 40 percent of the gross area of the structure's exterior walls and roof.

title: Supply Air
body: Air delivered to a conditioned space through ducts or plenums from the heat exchanger of a heating, cooling or ventilating system.

title: Supports
body: Devices for supporting, hanging and securing pipes, fixtures and equipment.

title: Sweep
body: A drainage fitting designed to provide a change in direction of a drain pipe of less than the angle specified by the amount necessary to establish the desired slope of the line. Sweeps provide a longer turning radius than bends and a less turbulent flow pattern (see "Bend" and "Elbow").

title: Temperature- And Pressure-Relief (T and P) Valve
body: A combination relief valve designed to function as both a temperature-relief and pressure-relief valve.

title: Temperature-Relief Valve
body: A temperature-actuated valve designed to discharge automatically at the temperature at which it is set.

title: Termite-Resistant Material
body: Pressure-preservative-treated wood in accordance with the AWPA standards in Section 317.1, naturally durable termite-resistant wood, steel, concrete, masonry or other approved material.

title: Thermal Isolation
body: Physical and space conditioning separation from conditioned spaces. The conditioned spaces shall be controlled as separate zones for heating and cooling or conditioned by separate equipment.

title: Thermal Resistance, R-Value
body: See "R-value."

title: Thermal Transmittance, U-factor
body: See "U-factor."

title: Thermostat
body: An automatic control device used to maintain temperature at a fixed or adjustable set point.

title: Electric Switch Type
body: A device that senses changes in temperature and controls electrically, by means of separate components, the flow of gas to the burner(s) to maintain selected temperatures.

title: Toilet, Gas-Fired
body: A packaged and completely assembled appliance containing a toilet that incinerates refuse instead of flushing it away with water.

title: Transition Fittings, Plastic to Steel
body: An adapter for joining plastic pipe to steel pipe. The purpose of this fitting is to provide a permanent, pressure-tight connection between two materials that cannot be joined directly one to another.

title: Trap
body: A fitting, either separate or built into a fixture, that provides a liquid seal to prevent the emission of sewer gases without materially affecting the flow of sewage or wastewater through it.

title: Trap Arm
body: That portion of a fixture drain between a trap weir and the vent fitting.

title: Trap Primer
body: A device or system of piping to maintain a water seal in a trap, typically installed where infrequent use of the trap would result in evaporation of the trap seal, such as floor drains.

title: Trap Seal
body: The trap seal is the maximum vertical depth of liquid that a trap will retain, measured between the crown weir and the top of the dip of the trap.

title: Trim
body: Picture molds, chair rails, baseboards, handrails, door and window frames, and similar decorative or protective materials used in fixed applications.

title: Truss Design Drawing
body: The graphic depiction of an individual truss, that describes the design and physical characteristics of the truss.

title: Tubular Daylighting Device (TDD)
body: A nonoperable fenestration unit primarily designed to transmit daylight from a roof surface to an interior ceiling via a tubular conduit. The basic unit consists of an exterior glazed weathering surface, a light-transmitting tube with a reflective interior surface, and an interior-sealing device such as a translucent ceiling panel. The unit may be factory assembled, or field assembled from a manufactured kit.

title: Type L Vent
body: A listed and labeled vent conforming to UL 641 for venting oil-burning appliances listed for use with Type L vents or with gas appliances listed for use with Type B vents.

title: U-factor (Thermal Transmittance)
body: The coefficient of heat transmission (air to air) through a building component or assembly, equal to the time rate of heat flow per unit area and unit temperature difference between the warm side and cold side air films (Btu/h • ft2 • °F) [W/(m2 • K)].

title: Underlayment
body: One or more layers of felt, sheathing paper, nonbituminous saturated felt, or other approved material over which a roof covering, with a slope of 2 to 12 (17-percent slope) or greater, is applied.

title: Unit Heater
body: A self-contained, automatically controlled, vented, fuel-gas-burning, space-heating appliance, intended for installation in the space to be heated without the use of ducts, and having integral means for circulation of air.

title: Unvented Room Heater
body: An unvented heating appliance designed for stationary installation and utilized to provide comfort heating. Such appliances provide radiant heat or convection heat by gravity or fan circulation directly from the heater and do not utilize ducts.

title: Vacuum Breaker
body: A device that prevents back-siphonage of water by admitting atmospheric pressure through ports to the discharge side of the device.

title: Valve (Chapter 24 Fuel Gas)
body: A device used in piping to control the gas supply to any section of a system of piping or to an appliance.

title: Appliance Shutoff
body: A valve located in the piping system, used to isolate individual appliances for purposes such as service or replacement.

title: Automatic
body: An automatic or semiautomatic device consisting essentially of a valve and an operator that control the gas supply to the burner(s) during operation of an appliance. The operator shall be actuated by application of gas pressure on a flexible diaphragm, by electrical means, by mechanical means or by other approved means.

title: Automatic Gas Shutoff
body: A valve used in conjunction with an automatic gas shutoff device to shut off the gas supply to a water-heating system. It shall be constructed integrally with the gas shutoff device or shall be a separate assembly.

title: Individual Main Burner
body: A valve that controls the gas supply to an individual main burner.

title: Main Burner Control
body: A valve that controls the gas supply to the main burner manifold.

title: Manual Main Gas-Control
body: A manually operated valve in the gas line for the purpose of completely turning on or shutting off the gas supply to the appliance, except to pilot or pilots that are provided with independent shutoff.

title: Manual Reset
body: An automatic shutoff valve installed in the gas supply piping and set to shut off when unsafe conditions occur. The device remains closed until manually reopened.

title: Service Shutoff
body: A valve, installed by the serving gas supplier between the service meter or source of supply and the customer piping system, to shut off the entire piping system.

title: Vapor Diffusion Port
body: A passageway for conveying water vapor from an unvented attic to the outside atmosphere.

title: Vapor Permeable
body: The property of having a moisture vapor permeance rating of 5 perms (2.9 × 10-10 kg/Pa • s • m2) or greater, where tested in accordance with the desiccant method using Procedure A of ASTM E96. A vapor permeable material permits the passage of moisture vapor.

title: Vapor Retarder Class
body: A measure of the ability of a material or assembly to limit the amount of moisture that passes through that material or assembly. Vapor retarder class shall be defined using the desiccant method with Procedure A of ASTM E96 as follows: Class I: ≤ 0.1 perm rating Class II: > 0.1 to ≤ 1.0 perm rating Class III: > 1.0 to ≤ 10 perm rating

title: Vent
body: A pipe or other conduit composed of factory-made components, containing a passageway for conveying combustion products and air to the atmosphere, listed and labeled for use with a specific type or class of appliance.

title: Special Gas Vent
body: A vent listed and labeled for use with listed Category II, III and IV gas appliances.

title: Type B Vent
body: A vent listed and labeled for use with appliances with draft hoods and other Category I appliances that are listed for use with Type B vents.

title: Type BW Vent
body: A vent listed and labeled for use with wall furnaces.

title: Type L Vent
body: A vent listed and labeled for use with appliances that are listed for use with Type L or Type B vents.

title: Vent Collar
body: See "Flue collar."

title: Vent Connector
body: That portion of a venting system that connects the flue collar or draft hood of an appliance to a vent.

title: Vent Damper Device, Automatic
body: A device intended for installation in the venting system, in the outlet of an individual, automatically operated fuel burning appliance and that is designed to open the venting system automatically where the appliance is in operation and to close off the venting system automatically where the appliance is in a standby or shutdown condition.

title: Vent Gases
body: Products of combustion from fuel-burning appliances, plus excess air and dilution air, in the venting system above the draft hood or draft regulator.

title: Breather
body: Piping run from a pressure-regulating device to the outdoors, designed to provide a reference to atmospheric pressure. If the device incorporates an integral pressure relief mechanism, a breather vent can also serve as a relief vent.

title: Relief
body: Piping run from a pressure-regulating or pressure-limiting device to the outdoors, designed to provide for the safe venting of gas in the event of excessive pressure in the gas piping system.

title: Vent Stack
body: A vertical vent pipe installed to provide circulation of air to and from the drainage system and that extends through one or more stories.

title: Vent System
body: Piping installed to equalize pneumatic pressure in a drainage system to prevent trap seal loss or blowback due to siphonage or back pressure.

title: Vented Appliance Categories
body: Appliances that are categorized for the purpose of vent selection are classified into the following four categories:

title: Category I
body: An appliance that operates with a non-positive vent static pressure and with a vent gas temperature that avoids excessive condensate production in the vent.

title: Category II
body: An appliance that operates with a non-positive vent static pressure and with a vent gas temperature that is capable of causing excessive condensate production in the vent.

title: Category III
body: An appliance that operates with a positive vent static pressure and with a vent gas temperature that avoids excessive condensate production in the vent.

title: Category IV
body: An appliance that operates with a positive vent static pressure and with a vent gas temperature that is capable of causing excessive condensate production in the vent.

title: Vented Room Heater
body: A vented self-contained, freestanding, non-recessed appliance for furnishing warm air to the space in which it is installed, directly from the heater without duct connections.

title: Vented Wall Furnace
body: A self-contained vented appliance complete with grilles or equivalent, designed for incorporation in or permanent attachment to the structure of a building, mobile home or travel trailer, and furnishing heated air circulated by gravity or by a fan directly into the space to be heated through openings in the casing. This definition shall exclude floor furnaces, unit heaters and central furnaces as herein defined.

title: Ventilation
body: The natural or mechanical process of supplying conditioned or unconditioned air to, or removing such air from, any space.

title: Ventilation Air
body: That portion of supply air that comes from outside (outdoors) plus any recirculated air that has been treated to maintain the desired quality of air within a designated space.

title: Venting
body: Removal of combustion products to the outdoors.

title: Venting System
body: A continuous open passageway from the flue collar or draft hood of an appliance to the outside atmosphere for the purpose of removing flue or vent gases. A venting system is usually composed of a vent or a chimney and vent connector, if used, assembled to form the open passageway.

title: Vertical Fenestration
body: See FENESTRATION, vertical.

title: Vertical Pipe
body: Any pipe or fitting that makes an angle of 45 degrees (0.79 rad) or more with the horizontal.

title: Vinyl Siding
body: A shaped material, made principally from rigid polyvinyl chloride (PVC), that is used to cover exterior walls of buildings.

title: Visible Transmittance (VT)
body: The ratio of visible light entering the space through the fenestration product assembly to the incident visible light, Visible Transmittance, includes the effects of glazing material and frame and is expressed as a number between 0 and 1.

title: Wall Heater, Unvented Type
body: A room heater of the type designed for insertion in or attachment to a wall or partition. Such heater does not incorporate concealed venting arrangements in its construction and discharges all products of combustion through the front into the room being heated.

title: Wall, Retaining
body: A wall not laterally supported at the top, that resists lateral soil load and other imposed loads.

title: Walls
body: Walls shall be defined as follows:

title: Load-Bearing Wall
body: A wall supporting any vertical load in addition to its own weight.

title: Nonbearing Wall
body: A wall which does not support vertical loads other than its own weight.

title: Waste
body: Liquidborne waste that is free of fecal matter.

title: Waste Pipe or Stack
body: Piping that conveys only liquid sewage not containing fecal material.

title: Waste Receptor
body: A floor sink, standpipe, hub drain or a floor drain that receives the discharge of one or more indirect waste pipes.

title: Water Distribution System
body: Piping that conveys water from the service to the plumbing fixtures, appliances, appurtenances, equipment, devices or other systems served, including fittings and control valves.

title: Water Heater
body: Any heating appliance or equipment that heats potable water and supplies such water to the potable hot water distribution system.

title: Water Main
body: A water supply pipe for public use.

title: Water Outlet
body: A valved discharge opening, including a hose bibb, through which water is removed from the potable water system supplying water to a plumbing fixture or plumbing appliance that requires either an air gap or backflow prevention device for protection of the supply system.

title: Water-Resistive Barrier
body: A material behind an exterior wall covering that is intended to resist liquid water that has penetrated behind the exterior covering from further intruding into the exterior wall assembly.

title: Water Service Pipe
body: The outside pipe from the water main or other source of potable water supply to the water distribution system inside the building, terminating at the service valve.

title: Water Supply System
body: The water service pipe, the water-distributing pipes and the necessary connecting pipes, fittings, control valves and appurtenances in or adjacent to the building or premises.

title: Wet Vent
body: A vent that receives the discharge of wastes from other fixtures.

title: Whole-House Mechanical Ventilation System
body: An exhaust system, supply system, or combination thereof that is designed to mechanically exchange indoor air for outdoor air where operating continuously or through a programmed intermittent schedule to satisfy the whole-house ventilation rate.

title: Winder
body: A tread with nonparallel edges.

title: Wood Structural Panel
body: A panel manufactured from veneers; or wood strands or wafers; bonded together with waterproof synthetic resins or other suitable bonding systems. Examples of wood structural panels are plywood, orientated strand board (OSB) or composite panels.

title: Yard
body: An open space, other than a court, unobstructed from the ground to the sky, except where specifically provided by this code, on the lot on which a building is situated.

title: Zone
body: A space or group of spaces within a building with heating or cooling requirements that are sufficiently similar so that desired conditions can be maintained throughout using a single controlling device.
